abstract: Seitel Inventors End Buyout Pla
snippet: Seitel Inventors End Buyout Pla
lead_paragraph: Seitel, a provider of geological data to oil companies that is in bankruptcy protection, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with shareholders on a reorganization plan, ending a proposed buyout by Berkshire Hathaway. Berkshire, the company run by the investor Warren E. Buffett, bought $255 million of Seitel's senior, unsecured notes this year. Seitel's shareholders had challenged the prepackaged plan that Seitel brought with it to bankruptcy protection. Under that plan, Berkshire, which is based in Omaha, was supposed to get control of Seitel, which is based in Houston, and the shareholders would have received $10.1 million, or about 40 cents a share. Instead, Berkshire and Ranch Capital, which also bought prebankruptcy debt, will be paid off under a plan to be detailed in papers filed with the court before a Jan. 30 hearing.

headline.main: SEITEL INVESTORS END BUYOUT PLAN BY BUFFETT
headline.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; SEITEL INVESTORS END BUYOUT PLAN BY BUFFETT

abstract: Itochu Corp and Taiyo Oil Co buy $24.4 milion of shares in South Korean oil refiner SK Corp in move that may help company fend off possible hostile takeover by Sovereign Asset Management; two companies purchase combined 0.74 percent stake in company; graph (S)
snippet: Itochu Corp and Taiyo Oil Co buy $24.4 milion of shares in South Korean oil refiner SK Corp in move that may help company fend off possible hostile takeover by Sovereign Asset Management; two companies purchase combined 0.74 percent stake in compa...
lead_paragraph: The Itochu Corporation of Japan and the Taiyo Oil Company bought $24.4 million of shares in the SK Corporation, South Korea's largest oil refiner, in a move that may help the company fend off a possible hostile takeover by Sovereign Asset Management, investors said. Itochu and Taiyo, both customers of SK, purchased a combined 0.74 percent stake in the company. Sovereign, a hedge fund based in Monaco that owns 14.99 percent of the SK Corporation, wants to oust directors at the company who favor using funds to bail out affiliates. Local SK Group creditors oppose Sovereign, as they may have to write off loans if cash is not provided to their units, and the sale to the two Japanese companies was seen by analysts as strengthening SK's hand.

abstract: Study finds that although most of big environmental effects of 1989 oil spill from Exxon Valdez tanker quickly dissipated, oil's toxic effects on various species around Prince William Soung persisted far longer than expected (S)
snippet: Study finds that although most of big environmental effects of 1989 oil spill from Exxon Valdez tanker quickly dissipated, oil's toxic effects on various species around Prince William Soung persisted far longer than expected (S)
lead_paragraph: Though most of the big environmental effects of the 1989 oil spill from the Exxon Valdez tanker quickly dissipated, the oil's toxic effects on various species around Prince William Sound persisted far longer than expected, a new analysis has found. The study, in the journal Science, found, for example, that residual oil in stream mouths harmed pink salmon eggs for at least four years after the accident. Pockets of oil have remained in coarse shorefront sediments, where they have continued to affect other life, the study said. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

lead_paragraph: The energy minister, Einar Steensnaes, decided to reopen much of the Barents Sea to oil drilling after a two-year suspension to study the potential effect of spills on marine life. At the same time, he said oil companies would not be permitted to resume exploration off the Lofoten Islands in the Norwegian Sea, saying oil companies could not guarantee the safety of rich cod-spawning waters there. Both areas are above the Arctic Circle. By opening one and keeping the other closed, Mr. Steensnaes drew the ire of both environmentalists and the oil industry. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

abstract: New Jersey McGreevey, fearing adverse impact on state's economy, fails to support proposal to increase state gasoline tax (S)
snippet: New Jersey McGreevey, fearing adverse impact on state's economy, fails to support proposal to increase state gasoline tax (S)
lead_paragraph: A proposal to increase the state gasoline tax was derailed last week when Governor McGreevey said he would not support the measure -- at least for now -- because he feared it would smother the state's economic recovery. A commission appointed by the governor had said that without the increase, the state's Transportation Trust Fund would soon run out of money to pay for construction and repair of roads and bridges. The increase had the backing of construction unions and some business groups, but many drivers opposed it. Democratic lawmakers were unable to win support from Republicans, even after they proposed using some of the tax increase to eliminate the highly unpopular tolls on the Garden State Parkway.

lead_paragraph: A grand jury has indicted four fishermen for defrauding a lobster restoration program developed after a 1996 oil spill that killed nearly eight million lobsters in Rhode Island Sound. Each lobsterman is accused of making more than $500 by falsely claiming he protected female lobsters. Under the program, which ended in June, lobstermen returned to the sea more than one million female lobsters, allowing them time to produce more eggs. Fishermen were paid for the number of lobsters they returned to the sea under an honor system. Katie Zezima (NYT)

abstract: WHEN Brian Appel was courting investors for his alternative energy company, he warned them, ''When you put in your $2 million and $10 million, there's a good chance you'll lose it, because no one's ever built anything like this before.'' Not exactly an enticing offer -- and hardly one you would expect from a man who was the Russell Stover Candy salesman of the year in 1981 and, four years later, the designer of a ticket-sale computer system that led to the formation of Ticketmaster.     Mr. Appel was only half joking when he approached investors with that seemingly self-defeating pitch in the late 1990's. After all, his goal -- to build a machine that turns animal byproducts into oil -- was something of a long shot. And when he flipped the switch three months ago on a machine capable of converting 200 tons a day of turkey feathers, guts and bones into liquid fuel, it was still too early to gauge the outcome.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Brian Appel was courting investors for his alternative energy company, he warned them, ''When you put in your $2 million and $10 million, there's a good chance you'll lose it, because no one's ever built anything like this before.'' Not exactly an enticing offer -- and hardly one you would expect from a man who was the Russell Stover Candy salesman of the year in 1981 and, four years later, the designer of a ticket-sale computer system that led to the formation of Ticketmaster.

abstract: Editorial says even people who tend to vote for Pres Bush, including Republican ranchers in Wyoming and sportsmen in Rocky Mountain Front, are not happy with what he is doing to federal lands; says that after deal struck by Interior Sec Gale Norton and Gov Michael Leavitt of Utah last Apr to remove federal protection from 2.6 million acres of land designated as potential wilderness, strategy has been to fast-track oil leases throughout West, mostly in areas worthy of wilderness designation in days past
snippet: Editorial says even people who tend to vote for Pres Bush, including Republican ranchers in Wyoming and sportsmen in Rocky Mountain Front, are not happy with what he is doing to federal lands; says that after deal struck by Interior Sec Gale Norto...
lead_paragraph: Last April, Interior Secretary Gale Norton and Gov. Michael Leavitt of Utah struck a deal that removed federal protection from about 2.6 million acres of land in Utah that her predecessor, Bruce Babbitt, had designated as potential wilderness. The consequences of that deal are now becoming clear. The Bureau of Land Management, part of Interior, recently announced plans to sell oil and gas leases on 16,000 acres in and near Desolation Canyon, a fragile landscape that would almost certainly have remained off limits under the Babbitt policy. Environmental groups have filed protests aimed not only at protecting Desolation Canyon but also at sending a larger message: that the fate of these and other lands of national significance should ultimately be decided by Congress, not the oil and gas industry.

abstract: French court convicts several senior executives of Elf Aquitaine of corruption and sentences them to jail terms and fines for their role in bilking oil company of hundreds of millions of dollars while it was still state-owned; graft at Elf stretched from halls of government in Paris through offshore bank accounts to government leaders in former French colonies; Elf's former chief executive Loik Le Floch-Prigent is convicted of embezzling company funds, given five-year prison sentence and fined $435,000; his deputy Alfred Sirven also receives five-year sentence on similar charges and is fined $1.15 million; third Elf executive Andre Tarallo is given four-year jail term and also fined $1.15 million; Elf has since been privatized and forms part of giant Total oil group; case recalled (M)

lead_paragraph: After a riveting eight-month trial that gave the French a replay of a decade of corporate malfeasance, a French court on Wednesday convicted several senior executives of the former French oil company Elf Aquitaine of corruption and sentenced them to jail terms and fines for their role in bilking Elf of hundreds of millions of dollars while it was still a state-owned company.

abstract: World Business Briefing:
snippet: World Business Briefing:
lead_paragraph: The new chief executive of Yukos, Simon G. Kukes, said that the company, which is Russia's largest oil producer, plans business as usual, despite the resignation this week of its embattled chief executive, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky. ''We don't plan any changes in company behavior, because it is developing normally,'' Mr. Kukes said at a news conference. ''Everything stays intact and we have a strong team.'' He left Russia for the United States in the 1970's, then worked with Phillips Petroleum and Amoco. Mr. Kukes joined Yukos in 1996, left in 1998 to become president of the Russian oil company TNK and brokered its joint venture with BP of Britain this year. He was named the chairman of Yukos last summer. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

abstract: Martin I Hoffert, New York University physics professor, reporting in journal Science, holds that wide variety of ideas is necessary to fight global warming; cites carbon dioxide, which is primary byproduct of fossil fuel usage, as heart of problem and suggests carbon dioxide emissions will reach twice preindustrial revolution levels by midcentury if significant changes in energy are not implemented; reports that 85 percent of world's energy use comes from fossil fuels; concept of carbon sequestration, which is capturing harmful carbons before they are released and storing them, most likely underground, is presented; solar energy and wind power discussed; large-scope concepts, such as satellite solar arrays in space and methods for scrubbing carbons out of air, presented; photos, charts (L)
snippet: Martin I Hoffert, New York University physics professor, reporting in journal Science, holds that wide variety of ideas is necessary to fight global warming; cites carbon dioxide, which is primary byproduct of fossil fuel usage, as heart of proble...
lead_paragraph: Suppose that over the next decade or two the forecasts of global warming start to come true. Color has drained from New England's autumns as maple trees die, and the Baltimore oriole can no longer be found south of Buffalo. The Dust Bowl has returned to the Great Plains, and Arctic ice is melting into open water. Upheavals in weather, the environment and life are accelerating around the world.

abstract: Editorial says Ilham Aliyev was elected to succeed his ailing father Heydar Aliyev as president of Azerbaijan through rigged election, and outside world did nothing to discourage him from raw display of power; notes Pres Bush was among world leaders who sent their congratulations; says United States should keep Aliyev at arm's length and avoid repeating unfortunate history of supporting autocrats who sit atop oil riches (National Edition)
snippet: Editorial says Ilham Aliyev was elected to succeed his ailing father Heydar Aliyev as president of Azerbaijan through rigged election, and outside world did nothing to discourage him from raw display of power; notes Pres Bush was among world leade...
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 15, Ilham Aliyev, businessman, playboy and novice politician, received a nice gift from his father -- the country of Azerbaijan. Heydar Aliyev had ruled Azerbaijan almost continuously for 34 years, first as an agent of the Soviet Politburo and then as an autocrat in his own right. When he became too ill to continue, he anointed his son to run for president in his place. Ilham Aliyev ran a rigged campaign, using all the powers of the state, and then celebrated his victory by arresting most of the opposition. To conclude this nasty exercise in dynasty building, Azerbaijan's new president accepted the fawning congratulations of the outside world -- including Washington.

lead_paragraph: Russian prosecutors charged an executive of Yukos, Russia's largest oil company, with tax evasion. The executive, Vasily S. Shakhnovsky, president of Yukos-Moscow, was charged with trying to evade taxes totaling 29 million rubles, or nearly $1 million, from 1998 to 2000, according to the Interfax news agency. He was later released and ordered to remain in the country. A spokesman for Yukos declined to comment on the charge. Erin E. Arvendlund (NYT)

abstract: Teppco Partners, US pipeline owner controlled by Duke Energy Corp, agrees to buy oil production and pipelines in Texas from Genesis Energy for $21 million to increase deliveries to Houston refineries; also acquires rights to sell about 12,000 barrels per day of oil production; lines will be integrated with Teppco's existing South Texas system (S)
snippet: Teppco Partners, US pipeline owner controlled by Duke Energy Corp, agrees to buy oil production and pipelines in Texas from Genesis Energy for $21 million to increase deliveries to Houston refineries; also acquires rights to sell about 12,000 barr...
lead_paragraph: Teppco Partners, a United States pipeline owner controlled by the Duke Energy Corporation, agreed to buy oil production and pipelines in Texas from Genesis Energy for $21 million to increase deliveries to Houston refineries. The acquisition includes 150 miles of small-diameter trunk lines that handle about 24,000 barrels of oil a day, Teppco said. The company, which is based in Houston, also acquired rights to sell about 12,000 barrels a day of oil production. The lines will be integrated with Teppco's existing South Texas system, the unit vice president, Sam Brown, said.

lead_paragraph: The Canadian energy group Enbridge announced plans to broaden the market for oil from Alberta in the United States by building a $600 million pipeline from northern Wisconsin to southern Illinois. The line, scheduled for completion in 2007, will connect with an existing pipeline between Chicago and Oklahoma, whose flow is being reversed to southbound from northbound. Canada's output of crude oil is expected to grow from 2.7 million barrels a day to 3.4 million over the next decade as it extracts more oil from deposits of oil sands. Enbridge said that the pipeline, with an initial capacity of 250,000 barrels a day would give it access to the St. Louis area and to Kentucky. Bernard Simon (NYT)

abstract: ConocoPhillips says that production of oil and natural gas fell 6 percent in the third quarter from previous three months and that oil-refining margins widened (S)
snippet: ConocoPhillips says that production of oil and natural gas fell 6 percent in the third quarter from previous three months and that oil-refining margins widened (S)
lead_paragraph: ConocoPhillips said yesterday that production of oil and natural gas fell 6 percent in the third quarter from the previous three months and that oil-refining margins widened. Production fell because of asset sales, seasonal declines and scheduled maintenance at fields in Alaska, Britain and Canada, the company said. Refining margins widened from the second quarter and plants ran at close to 95 percent capacity, the company said. Profit declined at its chemicals unit and pipeline operations, ConocoPhillips said. Debt at the end of the third quarter totaled $18.9 billion.

abstract: Spanish bank Santander Central Hispano makes $1.38 billion bid for additional 16 percent of oil company Compania Espanola de Petroleos (Cepsa); currently holds 20 percent stake in Cepsa; bid is being opposed by oil company Total, which owns 45 percent of Cepsa; graph (S)
snippet: Spanish bank Santander Central Hispano makes $1.38 billion bid for additional 16 percent of oil company Compania Espanola de Petroleos (Cepsa); currently holds 20 percent stake in Cepsa; bid is being opposed by oil company Total, which owns 45 per...
lead_paragraph: Santander Central Hispano, Spain's biggest bank, has bid 1.2 billion euros ($1.38 billion) for a larger stake in Compania Espanola de Petroleos, the oil company, raising expectations of a potential battle for control. Santander offered 28 euros a share in cash, or 17 percent more than Thursday's closing price, for 16 percent more of the company, known as Cepsa. Total, another European oil company and Cepsa's largest shareholder, indicated that it opposed the bid. Santander owns a fifth of Cepsa and has been sharing control with Total, which owns 45 percent.

abstract: Editorial says Congress has passed two mediocre bills that do not address country's long-term energy needs, and handed task of reconciling them to Sen Pete Domenici and Rep Billy Tauzin, both 'reliable allies' of fossil fuel industry; says almost certain outcome is tired compendium of tax breaks and subsidies for energy producers leavened by few gestures toward energy efficiency; says Democrats should filibuster this bill into extinction, but doubts they will because they, like Republicans, receive campaign money from established industries being protected in bill
snippet: Editorial says Congress has passed two mediocre bills that do not address country's long-term energy needs, and handed task of reconciling them to Sen Pete Domenici and Rep Billy Tauzin, both 'reliable allies' of fossil fuel industry; says almost ...
lead_paragraph: This country needs a purposeful long-term energy strategy that reduces its dependence on foreign oil and deals with climate change and all the other air-quality issues that are directly related to the burning of fossil fuels like oil and coal. So how has Congress chosen to develop such a strategy? By passing two mediocre energy bills and then handing the task of reconciling them to Senator Pete Domenici and Representative Billy Tauzin, both reliable allies of the fossil fuel industry (although Mr. Domenici is also a big fan of nuclear power) and neither a visionary thinker. Since Labor Day, these two veteran deal makers have been cherry-picking provisions they like, discarding those they don't and for good measure infuriating their colleagues by adding new items of their own.

abstract: Norwegian oil producer Statoil discloses that Securities and Exchange Commission has begun inquiry into its $15 million Iranian oil consulting contract with Horton Investment; contract has been subject of investigation by Norwegian government over alleged bribery payments made by Statoil to gain access to natural gas in Iran (S)
snippet: Norwegian oil producer Statoil discloses that Securities and Exchange Commission has begun inquiry into its $15 million Iranian oil consulting contract with Horton Investment; contract has been subject of investigation by Norwegian government over...
lead_paragraph: Norway's biggest oil producer, Statoil, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had started an inquiry into an Iranian consulting contract that is the focus of a bribery investigation in Norway. The S.E.C. has requested documents related to the $15 million contract with the consulting firm, Horton Investment, said Kai Nielsen, a spokesman for Statoil, based in Stavanger, Norway. The chief executive, Olav Fjell, and the chairman, Leif Terje Loeddesoel, resigned this week, less than two weeks after the Norwegian police began an investigation. The authorities in Norway are investigating whether Statoil paid bribes to gain the right to tap natural gas in Iran.

abstract: Statoil chairman Leif Terje Loeddesoel resigns as pressure increases on top managers in connection with 11-year, $15.5 million consulting contract that Norwegian police are investigating as possible attempt to buy influence in Iran; chief executive Olav Fjell is expected to face more questions from board about June 2002 contract with Horton Investment (S)
snippet: Statoil chairman Leif Terje Loeddesoel resigns as pressure increases on top managers in connection with 11-year, $15.5 million consulting contract that Norwegian police are investigating as possible attempt to buy influence in Iran; chief executiv...
lead_paragraph: The chairman of the board of Norway's flagship oil producer, Statoil, resigned as pressure increased on top managers in connection with an 11-year, $15.5 million consulting contract that Norwegian police are investigating as a possible attempt to buy influence in Iran. Statoil's chairman, Leif Terje Loeddesoel, who called the affair a ''gross violation'' of ethical guidelines last week but admitted knowing about it for several months without notifying the rest of the board, stepped down Sunday. The chief executive, Olav Fjell, is expected to face more questions from the board about the June 2002 contract with Horten Investment, a small Caribbean-registered company. It is led by a London-based Iranian whom the newspaper Dagens Naeringsliv has linked to Mehdi Hashemi Rafsanjani, the son of the former Iranian president, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani. The younger Mr. Rafsanjani has denied any connection to the case. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

abstract: Shell Exploration and Production Co, arm of Royal Dutch/Shell Group, sells 491 oil and natural gas wells in Michigan to Merit Energy Co for $445 million (S)
snippet: Shell Exploration and Production Co, arm of Royal Dutch/Shell Group, sells 491 oil and natural gas wells in Michigan to Merit Energy Co for $445 million (S)
lead_paragraph: The Shell Exploration and Production Company, an arm of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, agreed to sell 491 oil and natural gas wells in Michigan to the Merit Energy Company for $445 million. The sale also includes plants and lines that process and transport natural gas, said Fred Palmer, a spokesman for Shell Exploration, which is based in Houston. Royal Dutch/Shell Group aims to sell $2 billion worth of assets annually as part of a plan to focus on its highest-profit investments. With the sale announced yesterday, Shell has completed $3 billion in divestitures this year, Mr. Palmer said. Merit, which is based in Dallas and is closely held, buys and operates producing oil and gas properties on behalf of its investors.

abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Robert A Pape says presumed connection between suicide terrorism and Islamic fundamentalism is wrongheaded and may be encouraging domestic and foreign policies that are likely to worsen America's situation; says data from his study of every suicide bombing and attack around world from 1980 to 2001 show there is little connection between suicide terrorism and any religion, although religion is sometimes used as recruitment tool; says nearly all suicide terrorist campaigns have secular and strategic goal: to compel liberal democracies to withdraw military forces from territory that terrorists consider to be their homeland; says when democracies respond with heavy military offensives, it only incites more attacks and stirs public sympathy for terrorists; says best approach for states under fire is probably to focus on their own domestic security; says for United States, this means stepping up border and immigration controls and moving toward energy independence; drawing (M)
snippet: Op-Ed article by Prof Robert A Pape says presumed connection between suicide terrorism and Islamic fundamentalism is wrongheaded and may be encouraging domestic and foreign policies that are likely to worsen America's situation; says data from his...
lead_paragraph: Suicide terrorism has been on the rise around the world for two decades, but there is great confusion as to why. Since many such attacks -- including, of course, those of Sept. 11, 2001 -- have been perpetrated by Muslim terrorists professing religious motives, it might seem obvious that Islamic fundamentalism is the central cause. This presumption has fueled the belief that future 9/11's can be avoided only by a wholesale transformation of Muslim societies, which in turn was a core reason for broad public support of the invasion of Iraq.

lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court of India delayed a government asset-sale program and caused refiners' shares to fall when it said lawmakers must approve a $1.6 billion sale of shares in the Hindustan Petroleum Corporation and the Bharat Petroleum Corporation. snippet: Oil rig collapses off coasts of Louisiana and Mississippi throwing 41 workers into Gulf of Mexico; all 41 are rescued and diesel fuel leak is said to be minimal (S)
lead_paragraph: An oil rig collapsed off the coast of Louisiana and Mississippi, tipping drilling equipment and 41 workers into the Gulf of Mexico. Commercial vessels in the area and the Coast Guard rescued the workers. One of them was hospitalized, said the Parker Drilling Company, which owns the rig. The rig held 10,500 gallons of diesel fuel, but the amount of fuel leaked is minimal, the Coast Guard said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Statoil, Norway's largest oil producer, dismissed its head of international expansion and canceled an Iranian consulting contract as a result of a local police investigation into possible corruption. The consulting contract was a $15 million, 11-year agreement with Hortoil Investment undertaken to help Statoil invest in Iran. The National Authority for Investigation and Prosecution of Economic and Environmental Crime is investigating whether Statoil broke rules on dealing with officials of foreign states. Heather Timmons (NYT)

abstract: Marathon Oil Corp plans to cut 265 jobs, mostly at its Houston headquarters, and will close its Denver office to save more than $65 million per year (S)
snippet: Marathon Oil Corp plans to cut 265 jobs, mostly at its Houston headquarters, and will close its Denver office to save more than $65 million per year (S)
lead_paragraph: The Marathon Oil Corporation plans to cut 265 jobs, mostly at its Houston headquarters and will close its Denver office to save more than $65 million a year. The company will record $40 million in pretax expenses from a reorganization plan that includes consolidating the production offices in the United States. About 230 positions will be transferred to Houston from Denver, as well as Anchorage, Alaska; Cody, Wyo.; Lafayette, La.; Midland, Tex.; and Oklahoma City, Marathon said. About 40 percent of the expenses from the moves will be reported in the third quarter, and more cost cuts are likely, the company said.

abstract: Vestar Capital Partners agrees to buy Italian lubricant maker FL Selenia from British buyout firm Doughty Hanson for 670 million euros ($727 million) (S)
snippet: Vestar Capital Partners agrees to buy Italian lubricant maker FL Selenia from British buyout firm Doughty Hanson for 670 million euros ($727 million) (S)
lead_paragraph: The private equity firm Vestar Capital Partners said yesterday that it had agreed to buy an Italian lubricant maker, FL Selenia, for 670 million euros ($727 million). Vestar, which has its headquarters in New York, will buy Selenia from a British buyout company, Doughty Hanson. In 2000, Doughty bought Selenia from the Italian carmaker Fiat for about 400 million euros ($434 million). Fiat created Selenia 90 years ago to provide lubricants for its cars. Selenia, which also makes lubricants and fluids for the manufacturing industry, had sales last year of 477 million euros ($517 million).

lead_paragraph: Ametek Inc., a maker of electric motors, has agreed to buy the closely held Chandler Instruments Company for about $50 million to add to its oil and gas equipment business. Chandler Instruments, based in Tulsa, Okla., will post 2003 sales of about $30 million, Ametek said. Chandler makes measurement equipment for the oil and gas industry. The purchase adds to Ametek's drilling and exploration equipment and brings in instruments that analyze fuel and other liquids. Ametek, based in Paoli, Pa., will pay for the purchase by drawing on its $300 million credit line, a company spokesman, Bill Burke, said.

abstract: Editorial says new energy plan touted by Pres Bush and Congress is in fact dreary compendium of subsidies and tax breaks for coal, oil and gas industries that do nothing to address problems of global warming or country's dependence on foreign oil
snippet: Editorial says new energy plan touted by Pres Bush and Congress is in fact dreary compendium of subsidies and tax breaks for coal, oil and gas industries that do nothing to address problems of global warming or country's dependence on foreign oil
lead_paragraph: Every president starting with Richard Nixon and the 1973 oil embargo has promised to reduce America's ravenous appetite for oil while investing heavily in new energy sources. Mainly for lack of imagination and political will, all have failed. President Bush is headed in the same direction, for exactly the same reasons. What he and Congress exuberantly describe as their ''comprehensive energy plan'' is in fact a dreary compendium of subsidies and tax breaks for the coal, oil and gas industries that do nothing to address the problems of global warming or the country's dependence on foreign oil.

abstract: Ian Buruma article on conspiracy theories about so-called special relationship between Israel and US and supposed dominance of 'Jewish interests' in world affairs; while criticism of Israel is often denounced as anti-Semitism in US, anti-Zionism is acceptable in Europe, as is notion of too much Jewish influence in public life; Israel has zealous support among American Christian fundamentalists; foreign-policy hawks are inspired by Israel's use of pre-emptive strikes during Six-Day War of 1967, event that marks European animosity toward Israel, when former sympathizers felt free to publicly conclude Jews were behaving as badly as everyone else, or perhaps worse; end of European colonialism plays role in sympathies throughout Middle East, area whose alliances are at least partly determined by oil resources; Israel's political role in Washington's global strategy discussed; photos (L)
snippet: Ian Buruma article on conspiracy theories about so-called special relationship between Israel and US and supposed dominance of 'Jewish interests' in world affairs; while criticism of Israel is often denounced as anti-Semitism in US, anti-Zionism i...
lead_paragraph: The Jewish Problem pops up in the strangest places. In the winter of 1991, at the height of the first gulf war, I asked a right-wing Japanese politician who still wields considerable power in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party to explain the Japanese role in the Middle Eastern conflict. After clearing his throat with some perfunctory remarks about oil supplies and United States-Japan relations, he suddenly stopped midsentence, gave me a shrewd look and said: ''Look, we Japanese aren't stupid. We saw Henry Kissinger on TV. We know how America operates. We're perfectly well aware that this war is not about Kuwait. It's about Jewish interests. It's all about Israel.''

abstract: Editorial scores Bush administration for what it calls reckless and insupportable decision to eviscerate central provision of Clean Air Act and allow power plants, refineries and other industrial sites to spew millions of tons of unhealthy pollutants into air; calls decision transparent giveaway to Pres Bush's corporate allies; says lawsuits opposing move are expected to be filed by at least dozen states, and they could easily succeed
snippet: Editorial scores Bush administration for what it calls reckless and insupportable decision to eviscerate central provision of Clean Air Act and allow power plants, refineries and other industrial sites to spew millions of tons of unhealthy polluta...
lead_paragraph: President Bush's critics have watched with mounting frustration as his administration has compiled one of the worst environmental records in recent history without paying any real political price. One reason may be that the issues at stake are too regional, like forest fires or salmon recovery, or too remote, like global warming. But the administration itself may now have witlessly altered this dynamic with its reckless and insupportable decision to eviscerate a central provision of the Clean Air Act and allow power plants, refineries and other industrial sites to spew millions of tons of unhealthy pollutants into the air.

lead_paragraph: Husky Energy Inc., the Canadian oil and natural gas producer controlled by the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, agreed to buy the Marathon Oil Corporation's assets in western Canada for $588 million. Husky agreed to sell some of the Marathon properties to EOG Resources Inc. of Houston for $320 million, EOG said. Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., which is controlled by Mr. Li, holds about 35 percent of Husky stock. Including shares held by his family and at least one other company, he controls about 72 percent of Husky.

abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Unocal Corp will sign agreement, valued at estimated $1 billion, to drill offshore Shanghai as they try to tap world's second-largest energy market; Shell and Unocal will each take 20 percent in venture; China Petroleum and Chemical Corp and CNOOC Ltd will split rest (S)
snippet: Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Unocal Corp will sign agreement, valued at estimated $1 billion, to drill offshore Shanghai as they try to tap world's second-largest energy market; Shell and Unocal will each take 20 percent in venture; China Petroleum...
lead_paragraph: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Unocal Corporation will sign an agreement in Beijing today, valued at an estimated $1 billion, to drill offshore Shanghai as they try to tap the world's second-largest energy market, a partner in the project said. Shell and Unocal will each take 20 percent in a venture in the Xihu Trough, 450 kilometers (280 miles) southeast of Shanghai. The China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation and CNOOC Ltd., China's second- and third-largest oil producers, will split the rest. ''The gas discoveries will be piped to provinces and cities in east China, including Shanghai and Zhejiang,'' said Zheng Bin, a spokesman at CNOOC's parent, the China National Offshore Oil Corporation. The project, said to involve one of China's largest known offshore gas reserves, would give Shell a second supply of gas to sell to China's eastern coastal cities.

abstract: Contour Energy Co acquires Samson Investment Co for about $146 million, including assumption of debt; Samson explores for and produces oil and gas in various countries (S)
snippet: Contour Energy Co acquires Samson Investment Co for about $146 million, including assumption of debt; Samson explores for and produces oil and gas in various countries (S)
lead_paragraph: The Contour Energy Company, an oil and natural-gas exploration company that also develops wells, was bought by Samson Investment Company for about $146 million, including the assumption of debt. Contour has operations in Louisiana and in the Gulf of Mexico. Samson is based in Tulsa, Okla. Samson, which explores for and produces oil and gas in the Australia, Canada, Russia, the United States and Venezuela, is seeking to expand through acquisitions in Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas. The acquisition includes five fields and six platforms in the Gulf of Mexico, Samson said in the statement.

abstract: Barrie de la Maza Foundation, studying effects on Galician coastline, Spain, of oil spill last November from tanker Prestige, reports it will take 10 years and $3 billion for environmental recovery (S)
snippet: Barrie de la Maza Foundation, studying effects on Galician coastline, Spain, of oil spill last November from tanker Prestige, reports it will take 10 years and $3 billion for environmental recovery (S)
lead_paragraph: Galicia's craggy coastline, known for its rich marine life and home to at least six endangered species of sea birds, will take 10 years to recover from the oil spill caused by the sinking of the tanker Prestige last November, a study by the private Barrié de la Maza Foundation concludes. The report said that the cost of the cleanup could add up to more than $3 billion and that as many as 250,000 birds may have died. ''If our estimates are correct, this would represent the largest non-natural marine bird mortality known to Europe, comparable to that caused by the Exxon Valdez in Alaska,'' the study said. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

lead_paragraph: The shares of ABB Ltd., Europe's largest maker of power-transmission equipment, rose to their highest in 11 months on optimism that the Swiss company will sell most of its oil, gas and petrochemicals division for more than $1 billion. J.P. Morgan Partners, a unit of J.P. Morgan Chase and Company, has teamed with the British private-equity firms Candover Investments and 3i Group to buy the assets, according to a report in The Wall Street Journal. ABB, which is based in Zurich, wants to raise $2 billion through disposals this year to cut its $8.3 billion in debt.

lead_paragraph: I was stopped the other day at the U.S. Army checkpoint on the July 14 Bridge in the heart of Baghdad and told by the sergeant on duty that I didn't have the proper ID to enter the U.S. compound, which clogs the heart of the capital. So I called the U.S. Army officer I had an appointment with, and he offered to drive out to escort me in. To make certain he found me, I asked the sergeant who was running the checkpoint to take the phone and tell the officer exactly where we were standing. ''Sir,'' the sergeant said, ''we're on the enemy side of the July 14 bridge. . . .''

abstract: Greek oil tanker that had run aground off Karachi (Pakistan) beach breaks in two and leaks estimated 12,000 metric tons of oil; 35,000 metric tons is still on board, but officials believe there is no risk of further leakage (S)
snippet: Greek oil tanker that had run aground off Karachi (Pakistan) beach breaks in two and leaks estimated 12,000 metric tons of oil; 35,000 metric tons is still on board, but officials believe there is no risk of further leakage (S)
lead_paragraph: A Greek oil tanker that ran aground off a popular beach in the southern port city of Karachi three weeks ago split into two pieces and leaked an estimated 12,000 metric tons of oil, officials said. They played down the risk of further leaks from the stricken ship, but environmental groups called the situation an ''environmental, ecological and economic catastrophe.'' Roughly 35,000 metric tons is believed to remain on the ship, which officials say should hold, but local environmental groups fear it will not. A Pakistani television station reported that more than 100 people had been treated for respiratory and eye infections. Last night, oil washed ashore, and residents complained of dead fish, stinging vapors and pungent smells. Zulfiqar Shah (NYT)

abstract: India's Oil and Natural Gas Corp says strike will not hurt its production or output; thousands of employees of government-owned company have ceased work saying management negligence was cause of helicopter crash that killed 27 workers on Aug 11; unions have demanded resignations of India's Petroleum Min Ram Naik and company's chairman Subir Raha; say safety standards on offshore rigs are abysmal; photo (S)
snippet: India's Oil and Natural Gas Corp says strike will not hurt its production or output; thousands of employees of government-owned company have ceased work saying management negligence was cause of helicopter crash that killed 27 workers on Aug 11; u...
lead_paragraph: India's largest crude oil producer, the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation, said a strike would not hurt its production or output. Thousands of employees of the government-owned company have ceased work saying management negligence was the cause of a helicopter crash that killed 27 workers on Monday. The company produces 80 percent of India's crude oil output of more than 650,000 barrels a day. Unions have demanded the resignations of India's petroleum minister, Ram Naik, above, and the chairman of the company, Subir Raha. They said safety standards on offshore rigs were abysmal. Saritha Rai (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Three people died and 24 were missing in a helicopter crash in the Arabian Sea near Bombay. The Russian built MI-172 helicopter was ferrying employees of the state-owned Oil and Natural Gas Commission to an oil rig when it went down three minutes after takeoff. abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Manik Talwani says largest deposits of oil in world are in Venezuela and Canada, but they consist of forms of 'heavy oil' that require expensive process to be converted into so-called syncrude; says expanding heavy oil production to make it significant part of American energy strategy will require huge investment; says policy makers must decide whether risks of global market instability and foreign-policy consequences of relying on Middle Eastern oil are severe enough to make switching to heavy oil a priority; says payoff is clear, not only for Canada and Venezuela but also for American energy security and foreign policy (M)
snippet: Op-Ed article by Prof Manik Talwani says largest deposits of oil in world are in Venezuela and Canada, but they consist of forms of 'heavy oil' that require expensive process to be converted into so-called syncrude; says expanding heavy oil produc...
lead_paragraph: America has many reasons for its risky involvement in Middle East politics, but there is no question that dependence on imported oil plays a very large role. The fact is, however, that the largest deposits of oil in the world are not in the Middle East -- or in Russia or off West Africa or in the Caspian Sea area, for that matter. They are in two Western Hemisphere countries: Venezuela and Canada.

abstract: Tina Rosenberg article on worldwide government corruption, how it is manifested, its causes and its impact on societies; cites Mexico, where Vicente Fox vowed to liberate country from corruption when he was sworn in, raising public's expectations, but failed because corruption is so deeply entrenched in culture and political system; some realities about worldwide corruption are emerging: that most corrupt nations are poor, that big nations tend to be less corrupt, that Democracy can be instrumental in deterring corruption and that location and oil resources may be contributing factors; photos (L)
snippet: Tina Rosenberg article on worldwide government corruption, how it is manifested, its causes and its impact on societies; cites Mexico, where Vicente Fox vowed to liberate country from corruption when he was sworn in, raising public's expectations,...
lead_paragraph: When Vicente Fox was sworn in as president of Mexico on Dec. 1, 2000, he carried with him a huge burden: the public's expectation that he would liberate from corruption a country that had become symbolic of the scourge. Fox was the first Mexican president from an opposition party after 71 years of autocratic control by the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or P.R.I., which maintained its grip on Mexico principally through corruption.

abstract: Anadarko Petroleum Corp to sell about $100 million in assets by end of year to finance its drilling operations and reduce company debt; will also cut 400 jobs and lower annual costs by $100 million (S)
snippet: Anadarko Petroleum Corp to sell about $100 million in assets by end of year to finance its drilling operations and reduce company debt; will also cut 400 jobs and lower annual costs by $100 million (S)
lead_paragraph: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation will sell $100 million of assets by the end of the year to help finance its drilling program and reduce debt, its chief executive, Robert Allison, said yesterday. The asset sale had been planned, and properties to be sold are mostly offshore and ''pretty scattered,'' Mr. Allison said on a conference call with analysts and investors. Shares of Anadarko, an oil and natural gas producer, have lagged those of rivals in the last 18 months, prompting the board in March to replace John Seitz as chief executive with Mr. Allison, his predecessor. Anadarko said on Thursday that it would eliminate 400 jobs and cut annual costs by $100 million. Its shares fell $1.12, or 2.6 percent, to $42.68.

snippet: Howard Dean will outline his stand on environmental issues in San Francisco, calling for auto industry to build cars by 2015 that get 40 miles a gallon, and for 20 percent of nations electricity to come from renewable sources by 2020; will say tha...
lead_paragraph: Howard Dean, a Democratic presidential candidate, is calling for the auto industry to build cars that get 40 miles per gallon by 2015 and for 20 percent of the nation's electricity to come from renewable sources by 2020. In an environmental speech prepared for delivery in San Francisco on Thursday, Dr. Dean, the former Vermont governor, also says that as president he would close the loophole that exempts sport utility vehicles from gas-mileage standards. He says he would make the Environmental Protection Agency cabinet level and work to re-establish the Clinton administration rules limiting roads in national forests. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

abstract: Archer Daniels Midland, largest producer of ethanol in country, is signing supply contracts with East Coast gasoline refiners that are anticipating that ban on methyl tertiary butyl ether in New York and Connecticut will come into force at end of year (S)
snippet: Archer Daniels Midland, largest producer of ethanol in country, is signing supply contracts with East Coast gasoline refiners that are anticipating that ban on methyl tertiary butyl ether in New York and Connecticut will come into force at end of ...
lead_paragraph: Archer Daniels Midland, the largest producer of ethanol in the country, is signing supply contracts with East Coast gasoline refiners that are anticipating that a ban on methyl tertiary butyl ether, or M.T.B.E., in New York and Connecticut will come into force at the end of the year. Gasoline refiners use ethanol to stretch supplies and cut emissions by raising the fuel's oxygen levels. About 75 percent of California's gasoline is currently being blended with ethanol as refiners in the state adjust to a similar M.T.B.E. ban. The additive was found to leak from storage tanks and foul drinking water supplies.

abstract: Oil Search Ltd to buy ChevronTexaco Corp's Papua New Guinea oil and gas interests for $96.6 million, increasing annual oil output almost 20 percent; weighs selling assets to third party (S)
snippet: Oil Search Ltd to buy ChevronTexaco Corp's Papua New Guinea oil and gas interests for $96.6 million, increasing annual oil output almost 20 percent; weighs selling assets to third party (S)
lead_paragraph: Papua New Guinea's biggest oil and gas company, Oil Search Ltd., said it had agreed to buy the local oil and gas interests of the ChevronTexaco Corporation for $96.6 million, increasing annual oil output almost 20 percent. The acquisition will immediately add to the company's earnings, Oil Search said. The acquisition includes stakes in four crude-oil producing projects, three oil discoveries and two gas fields. The company, based in Port Moresby, said it might sell the assets to a third party.

snippet: Polish government says it will hold exclusive talks for control of about 70 percent of Poland's steel industry with LNM Holdings, British-Dutch steelmaker largely owned by Indian-born billionaire Lakshmi N Mittal; rejects rival bid from US Steel; ...
lead_paragraph: The Polish government said it would hold exclusive talks for control of about 70 percent of Poland's steel industry with LNM Holdings, a British-Dutch steelmaker, largely owned by the Indian-born billionaire Lakshmi N. Mittal. It rejected a rival bid from U.S. Steel of Pittsburgh. The government canceled the expected $600 million sale of the oil refiner Lotos to Poland's largest energy company, PKN Orlen and the British-based investment group, Rotch Energy. Instead, the Treasury ministry announced that it would merge Lotos, previously known as Rafineria Gdanska, with three ailing, government-owned refineries in Southern Poland. Peter S. Green (NYT)

abstract: El Paso Corp sells its asphalt business to Trigeant EP Ltd for $90 million; sells Louisiana Lease Crude oil unit to Plains All America Pipeline for $12 million (S)
snippet: El Paso Corp sells its asphalt business to Trigeant EP Ltd for $90 million; sells Louisiana Lease Crude oil unit to Plains All America Pipeline for $12 million (S)
lead_paragraph: The El Paso Corporation, an owner of natural gas pipelines, said it would sell two businesses for $102 million. It also said it recorded second-quarter expenses of as much as $1.5 billion as it wrote down the value of assets. El Paso is selling an asphalt business to Trigeant EP Ltd. for about $90 million, including inventory valued at about $55 million, the company said. The Louisiana Lease Crude unit was sold to Plains All American Pipeline for about $12 million, including inventory valued at about $2 million, El Paso said. El Paso, which is based in Houston, recorded pretax expenses of $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion in the second quarter to account for a drop in the value of some assets, including an oil refinery in Aruba.

lead_paragraph: In yet another attack on the oil magnate Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, left, Russian authorities began investigating accusations of tax evasion at Mr. Khodorkovsky's flagship oil company, Yukos Oil. The general prosecutor's office began reviewing charges by a deputy in the Russian Parliament that Yukos, Russia's biggest oil company, did not pay all its taxes last year. The authorities have been investigating companies associated with Mr. Khodorkovsky, but this was the first time the inquiries touched Yukos, which is popular among foreign investors. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

Arun Shourie, minister for disinvestment, information technology and communications, announced after a meeting of a government panel on privatization on Thursday that the government would sell its stakes in the software company CMC; an international phone and Internet service provider, Videsh Sanchar Nigam; the Indian Petrochemicals Corporation; an oil retailer, IBP; and the Bharat Aluminium Company. All of the companies were privatized in the last three years. Saritha Rai (NYT)

abstract: Caspian Pipeline Consortium, headed by ChevronTexaco, that owns pipeline that ships oil from Kazakhstan to Russian port of Novorossiisk, is preparing to take first delivery of Russian crude; group signs agreement with KalmTEK to ship Russian oil through its network (S)
snippet: Caspian Pipeline Consortium, headed by ChevronTexaco, that owns pipeline that ships oil from Kazakhstan to Russian port of Novorossiisk, is preparing to take first delivery of Russian crude; group signs agreement with KalmTEK to ship Russian oil t...
lead_paragraph: A consortium headed by ChevronTexaco that owns a pipeline that ships oil from Kazakhstan to the Russian port of Novorossiisk, said it was preparing to take the first delivery of Russian crude. The group, called the Caspian Pipeline Consortium, signed an agreement with KalmTEK, a state-owned Russian company, to ship the Russian oil through its network. The group did not specify exactly when the shipment would be made. It said the agreement would bring the start of Russian oil flowing through the network, which currently carries only crude from Kazakhstan, even though it runs through Russian territory.

abstract: Platon Lebedev, chairman of Menatep, which owns 61% of Yukos, Russia's largest oil company, is arrested and his colleague Mikhail B Khodorkovsky is interrogated about alledged embezzlement; claims charges are false; photo (S)
snippet: Platon Lebedev, chairman of Menatep, which owns 61% of Yukos, Russia's largest oil company, is arrested and his colleague Mikhail B Khodorkovsky is interrogated about alledged embezzlement; claims charges are false; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The authorities interrogated the oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, left, in an embezzling case against a colleague that Moscow business leaders say is trumped up. On Wednesday, the General Prosecutor's office arrested the colleague, Platon Lebedev, chairman of Menatep, which owns 61 percent of Russia's largest oil company, Yukos, Mr. Khodorkovsky's main asset. Meanwhile, a Kremlin official, who asked that his name not be used, denied that the Kremlin had any part in the arrest, which took the Russian business community and political elite by surprise. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

abstract: Sakhalin Energy Investment Co, consortium led by Royal Dutch/Shell that is producing oil in waters off Russia's eastern coast, says it has shipped its first cargo of crude oil to ports in Washington State and Alaska (S)
snippet: Sakhalin Energy Investment Co, consortium led by Royal Dutch/Shell that is producing oil in waters off Russia's eastern coast, says it has shipped its first cargo of crude oil to ports in Washington State and Alaska (S)
lead_paragraph: The Sakhalin Energy Investment Company, the consortium led by Royal Dutch/Shell that is producing oil in the waters off Russia's eastern coast, said that it had shipped its first cargo of crude oil to the west coast of the United States. The 700,000 barrels of oil is headed to ports in Washington and Alaska, the company said. Sakhalin Energy was the first consortium to begin producing oil in Russia's far east several years ago. It normally ships to buyers in Russia and Asia. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

abstract: Editorial calls for United States government to endorse Publish What You Pay campaign, which would require publicly traded oil and gas companies to reveal payments they make to each country where they work; says plan would give companies tool to resist paying huge bribes and to breach confidentiality agreements they have signed with corrupt governments, as well as assuring that oil and gas revenues are used to create more prosperous and stable societies
snippet: Editorial calls for United States government to endorse Publish What You Pay campaign, which would require publicly traded oil and gas companies to reveal payments they make to each country where they work; says plan would give companies tool to r...
lead_paragraph: It is a widely noted paradox that striking oil can be disastrous for a poor country. In Nigeria, Sudan, Angola, Venezuela and many other places, oil and gas have brought corruption and strife. Some of the reasons, such as oil's distorting effects on exchange rates, trade balances and credit, are hard to combat. But around the world, governments and oil companies are beginning to embrace a simple change that can help: strip the secrecy from the deals.

abstract: Russian oil producer Lukoil sets up joint venture with country's natural gas monopoly Gazprom to develop large oil and gas field in Caspian Sea; each company will own half of new concern, which will work together with Kazakhstan's natural gas company Kazmunaigaz to develop field (S)
snippet: Russian oil producer Lukoil sets up joint venture with country's natural gas monopoly Gazprom to develop large oil and gas field in Caspian Sea; each company will own half of new concern, which will work together with Kazakhstan's natural gas comp...
lead_paragraph: The Russian oil producer Lukoil set up a joint venture with the country's natural gas monopoly, Gazprom, to develop a large oil and gas field in the Caspian Sea. Each company will own half of the new concern, which will work together with Kazakhstan's natural gas company, Kazmunaigaz, to develop the field. The field, near the border between Russia and Kazakhstan in the waters of the Caspian, is estimated to contain about 3.8 billion barrels of oil equivalent, Lukoil said in a statement. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

abstract: Unit Corp, driller of land-based oil and natural-gas wells, acquires rival PetroCorp for about $190 million in cash and stock to expand its holdings in Louisiana and Texas (S)
snippet: Unit Corp, driller of land-based oil and natural-gas wells, acquires rival PetroCorp for about $190 million in cash and stock to expand its holdings in Louisiana and Texas (S)
lead_paragraph: The Unit Corporation, a driller of land-based oil and natural-gas wells, said it had agreed to buy a rival, PetroCorp, for about $190 million in cash and stock to expand its holdings in Louisiana and Texas. The purchase price includes two million Unit shares, valued at $41.8 million based on Monday's closing price, Unit said. The offer is valued at $14.50 a share of PetroCorp. The acquisition will increase earnings and cash flow immediately, said Larry D. Pinkston, the chief financial officer. Both companies are based in Tulsa, Okla.

abstract: Frank Hopf Jr is sentenced with other former managers at Olympic Pipe Line Co for 1999 pipeline rupture that spilled gasoline into a Bellingham, Wash, creek, fueling fireball that killed 3 youths; receives six months in prison and three years probation (S)
snippet: Frank Hopf Jr is sentenced with other former managers at Olympic Pipe Line Co for 1999 pipeline rupture that spilled gasoline into a Bellingham, Wash, creek, fueling fireball that killed 3 youths; receives six months in prison and three years prob...
lead_paragraph: Three former Olympic Pipe Line Company managers were sentenced for the 1999 pipeline rupture that spilled 225,000 gallons of gasoline into a Bellingham creek, fueling a fireball and killing an 18-year-old man and two 10-year-old boys. Judge Barbara Jacobs Rothstein of Federal District Court issued the stiffest sentence to Frank Hopf Jr., Olympic's manager at the time, who was given six months in jail and three years of probation. lead_paragraph: The huge effort to restore Iraq's oil industry begins every day two hours south of the Iraq-Kuwait border, at the lavish Crowne Plaza Hotel in Kuwait City. No sooner does the lobby restaurant open at 5 a.m. than a line of middle-aged men in jumpsuits, golf shirts and identical tan caps forms at the breakfast buffet, eschewing the mezzeh and labneh for French toast, home fries and beef bacon. Outside, a couple of dozen silver S.U.V.'s are lined up, and after a quick breakfast the men are off in a swift northbound convoy, each car marked with the sideways V of duct tape that designates American and British vehicles. The road knifes across a packed pebble desert as flat as a griddle, with hardly a plant or a rock gentling the view to a hazy 360-degree horizon. But nobody's minding the scenery.

abstract: Petroleos Mexicanos will invest $13.75 billion this year, its largest investment budget ever; will spend $6.4 billion in next three years to construct 47 offshore oil platforms, raising daily production at three main oil fields to 1.5 million barrels of crude and 1.4 billion cubic feet of natural gas; Mexico's Pres Vicente Fox says Pemex plans to spend $30 billion in next 15 years to develop Chicontepec Reserve, with estimated reserves of 18 billion barrels (S)
snippet: Petroleos Mexicanos will invest $13.75 billion this year, its largest investment budget ever; will spend $6.4 billion in next three years to construct 47 offshore oil platforms, raising daily production at three main oil fields to 1.5 million barr...
lead_paragraph: Mexico's state-run oil monopoly, Petróleos Mexicanos, will invest $13.75 billion this year, its largest investment budget ever, the company said. Pemex, as the company is known, also said it would spend $6.4 billion in the next three years to construct 47 offshore oil platforms, raising daily production at three main oil fields to 1.5 million barrels of crude and 1.4 billion cubic feet of natural gas. Speaking in the Gulf state of Veracruz, President Vicente Fox said Pemex planned to spend $30 billion in the next 15 years to develop the Chicontepec Reserve, with estimated reserves of 18 billion barrels. Under Mr. Fox, Pemex has pushed for increased investment to modernize the creaky giant and raise output. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

Patterson-UTI is based in Snyder, Tex.

abstract: Editorial says Justice Department wants to end use of lawsuits brought under Alien Tort Claims Act, reversal that would effectively grant impunity to those who abuse human rights abroad; says what has drawn Bush administration's wrath is suits accusing energy companies of committing serious human rights abuses in other countries; says possibility of suits has been major impulse for oil and gas companies to work with human rights groups to change their practices (M)
snippet: Editorial says Justice Department wants to end use of lawsuits brought under Alien Tort Claims Act, reversal that would effectively grant impunity to those who abuse human rights abroad; says what has drawn Bush administration's wrath is suits acc...
lead_paragraph: In 1996, American lawyers filed a class-action lawsuit accusing Swiss banks of withholding the assets of Holocaust victims. Two years later, the suit was settled, and a fund of $1.25 billion was established to pay those with legitimate claims. The suit was filed under the Alien Tort Claims Act -- a little-known statute that is a powerful tool for promoting human rights. But now the Justice Department wants to end the law's use in such suits, a reversal that would effectively grant impunity to those who abuse human rights abroad.

lead_paragraph: China's top offshore oil producer, CNOOC Ltd., said yesterday that it would pay $348 million for a 5.3 percent stake in the North West Shelf project, Australia's largest oil and gas venture, to meet growing gas demand in China. The project, led by Woodside Petroleum Ltd., beat rivals in Qatar and Indonesia last year to supply about 3.3 million metric tons of liquefied natural gas a year for 25 years to China's first L.N.G. import terminal at Guangdong, in the nation's south.

lead_paragraph: BP, the British oil company, reported quarterly profit of £2.3 billion ($3.7 billion) for the first three months of the year, more than double the period a year earlier. Profit was helped by soaring oil prices resulting from a sequence of world events including the run-up to the war in Iraq, a national strike in Venezuela and civil unrest in Nigeria. A fall in oil prices from $31 a barrel to yesterday's five-month low of $23 a barrel is expected to lead to a slump in profits at BP during the current quarter. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

abstract: Thousands of workers at two government-owned oil companies Hindustan Petroleum Corp and Bharat Petroleum Corp begin three-day strike to protest privatization of companies; workers fear that privatization will lead to job losses (S)/
snippet: Thousands of workers at two government-owned oil companies Hindustan Petroleum Corp and Bharat Petroleum Corp begin three-day strike to protest privatization of companies; workers fear that privatization will lead to job losses (S)/
lead_paragraph: Thousands of workers at two government-owned oil companies, the Hindustan Petroleum Corporation and the Bharat Petroleum Corporation, began a three-day strike to protest the privatization of the companies. The workers fear that privatization will lead to job losses. The government has already initiated the sell-off of both Hindustan Petroleum and Bharat Petroleum, and the asset sales are expected to go through despite the labor opposition. The strike, in defiance of a court ruling, is also unlikely to disrupt oil supply in the country as refineries continue to operate. The government proposes to sell 34.01 percent of Hindustan Petroleum to a strategic partner, and bidders have already expressed interest. The two oil companies control nearly half of India's retail market.

lead_paragraph: The state oil company Petróleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, has made its biggest offshore discovery since 1996, a new 1.9 billion barrel field off the coast of the northeastern state of Sergipe. The find, announced by the National Oil Agency, may eventually take Brazil one step closer to fuel self-sufficiency and is important for Petrobras because the oil found is of a similar quality to the crude it now imports and mixes with its main supply before it is refined. Petrobras confirmed the find but declined to give details. Tony Smith (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. increased its stake in the PetroChina Company's publicly traded stock to 7.2 percent, making it the No. 3 investor in the company, China's largest oil producer, PetroChina said. Berkshire, the holding company run by Warren E. Buffett, bought 80.5 million shares in the government-controlled company on April 9, raising its holding to 1.26 billion shares, PetroChina reported to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.

abstract: El Paso Corp sells its Florida petroleum terminals and tug-and-barge operations to TransMontaigne for about $155 million; terminals sold average of 29,000 barrels of fuel per day last year to cruise-ship operators (S)
snippet: El Paso Corp sells its Florida petroleum terminals and tug-and-barge operations to TransMontaigne for about $155 million; terminals sold average of 29,000 barrels of fuel per day last year to cruise-ship operators (S)
lead_paragraph: The El Paso Corporation has agreed to sell its Florida petroleum terminals and tug-and-barge operations to TransMontaigne for about $155 million. The terminals sold an average of 29,000 barrels of fuel a day last year to cruise-ship operators, TransMontaigne said. The terminals, in Jacksonville, Cape Canaveral, Port Manatee, Port Everglades and Fisher Island, can collectively store as much as five million barrels of fuel. TransMontaigne, which transports and stores petroleum products and chemicals, already owns three Florida terminals capable of storing a total of 1.2 million barrels, the company said. Transmontaigne is based in Denver. El Paso is based in Houston.

lead_paragraph: There are two types of people who do well in dictatorships: those who make themselves politically indispensable, doing whatever bit of wickedness the dictatorship requires, and those who make themselves economically indispensable, keeping the trains and refineries running smoothly. Dathar Khashab, the chain-smoking, overalls-wearing 58-year-old director general of the Daura oil refinery near Baghdad, falls into the latter category.

abstract: ChevronTexaco Corp says it will sell oil and natural gas fields in Papua New Guinea, resulting in its exit from $3.5 billion Exxon Mobil Corp project (S)
snippet: ChevronTexaco Corp says it will sell oil and natural gas fields in Papua New Guinea, resulting in its exit from $3.5 billion Exxon Mobil Corp project (S)
lead_paragraph: The ChevronTexaco Corporation said yesterday that it would sell oil and natural gas fields in Papua New Guinea, resulting in its exit from a $3.5 billion project of the Exxon Mobil Corporation. ChevronTexaco will sell stakes in the Kutubu, Moran, Gobe Main and South East Gobe oil fields as well as resign as operator, the company said. The sale of the fields, which produce about 53,000 barrels of oil a day, follows a review of its global portfolio, it said.

lead_paragraph: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, left, the chief executive of the Russian oil producer Yukos Oil, said he would resign in 2007. lead_paragraph: Formal expressions of interest in bidding for a one-third stake in Hindustan Petroleum were filed by 12 companies by the deadline Monday night, according to Indian news reports. The government's privatization ministry was closed yesterday for a holiday and did not issue a list, but news accounts said that ChevronTexaco, BP, Exxon Mobil, Royal Dutch/Shell, Petronas and Saudi Aramco were among the foreign oil companies making initial bids. Essar, an Indian conglomerate, said that it, too, had bid for the stake, which at current market prices is worth about $630 million. Saritha Rai (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Lukoil, one of Russia's largest oil companies, said it would defend its rights to a large Iraqi oil field in court if Western oil companies made claims to the field during or after military action in Iraq. Leonid Fedun, a vice president at Lukoil, said in a telephone interview that his company would sue any usurping company in international court in Geneva. Lukoil, said Mr. Fedun, is confident about the contract, which was concluded with the Iraqi government, but never advanced because of economic sanctions imposed on Iraq by the United Nations. abstract: World Business
snippet: World Business
lead_paragraph: José Eduardo Dutra, a Workers' Party senator and former union leader, was tapped to head Petróleo Brasileiro, signaling that the company may focus more on the government's economic goals than on profit. Andre Singer, a spokesman for President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, confirmed the appointment. Mr. Dutra, 43, will probably carry out Mr. da Silva's promises of having Petrobras, the state oil company, build oil platforms in Brazil and use the company to create jobs. Mr. da Silva's energy minister said this week that the government might restore price controls and fuel subsidies to stem inflation. A geologist, Mr. Dutra worked seven years at Petrobras. Mr. Dutra was a union leader, and soon became leader of Mr. da Silva's Workers' Party. In 1994, he was elected senator in Brazil's northeastern state of Sergipe and this year made an unsuccessful bid for state governor.

abstract: Sunoco Inc to buy Eagle Point refinery, Westville, NJ, from El Paso Corp for at least $130 million (S)
snippet: Sunoco Inc to buy Eagle Point refinery, Westville, NJ, from El Paso Corp for at least $130 million (S)
lead_paragraph: Sunoco Inc., a leading oil refiner, agreed to buy the Eagle Point refinery in New Jersey from the El Paso Corporation for at least $130 million. The refinery, in Westville, has the capacity to process 150,000 barrels of crude oil a day, Sunoco said. The purchase price will rise to include crude oil and refined fuel inventories when the deal closes in the second or third quarter, Sunoco said. After the purchase, Sunoco, which is based in Philadelphia, will have a 29 percent share of the 1.71 million barrels of daily refining capacity in a 17-state region of the East Coast, government figures show.

snippet: World Business Briefing: Russia: Deal For Oil Asse
lead_paragraph: The Russian oil companies Sibneft and Tyumen Oil said they had reached an agreement on jointly owned assets that could have caused problems for a new multibillion-dollar deal by BP and Tyumen. Under the terms of the preliminary agreement, Sibneft will give up its stake in an international holding company that owns Tyumen, in exchange for monetary compensation. The two Russian companies will evenly divide most of the assets of Slavneft, a company they bought late last year. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT).

snippet: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column argues that Saudi Arabia's antimodern brand of Islam known as Wahhabism combined with their oil wealth is destabilizing force in world; says that by financing schools that foster least tolerate version of Islam, Saud...
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the recent terrorist bombings in Riyadh, Saudi officials seem to have -- pardon the expression -- gotten religion. They say they now understand that suicide terrorism in the name of Islam is as much a threat to them as it is to the open societies of the West. This time, they insist, they're going to crack down on their extremists. I hope so, but I fear we have a deeper problem with Saudi Arabia. I fear it is the Soviet Union. I fear it is unreformable.

abstract: Thomas M Hayes of Saybolt Inc is convicted by federal jury in New Jersey of aiding the bogus testing of gasoline, which allowed millions of gallons of substandard gasoline to be sold in violation of Clean Air Act (S)
snippet: Thomas M Hayes of Saybolt Inc is convicted by federal jury in New Jersey of aiding the bogus testing of gasoline, which allowed millions of gallons of substandard gasoline to be sold in violation of Clean Air Act (S)
lead_paragraph: The former vice president of a petroleum-testing company has been convicted of aiding the bogus testing of gasoline, allowing millions of gallons of substandard gasoline to be sold. A federal jury on Friday found the former vice president of Saybolt Inc., Thomas M. Hayes, guilty of conspiring to violate the Clean Air Act, making false statements to the federal Environmental Protection Agency, committing mail fraud and obstructing justice. Mr. Hayes faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Saybolt, which pleaded guilty in 1999 to conspiracy to falsify documents, has been fined $3.4 million. Stacy Albin (NYT)

abstract: Exco Resources sells company
snippet: Exco Resources sells company
lead_paragraph: Exco Resources, an oil and natural gas producer, agreed yesterday to sell the company to Exco Holdings, formed by the chief executive, Douglas Miller, and other managers, for $18 a common share. The agreement is valued at $350 million, including $232 million in cash, $110 million in assumed debt, and transaction fees, said Exco's president and treasurer, Ted W. Eubank, one of the managers who are taking the company private to cut administrative costs. A committee of independent board members is recommending shareholder approval, Exco said. The sale price represented a 3.4 percent premium over Exco's closing price of $17.41 on Jan. 8, when the offer was made, and a 4.6 percent premium over Tuesday's close of $17.20.

abstract: Plains Exploration and Production Co acquires 3TEC Energy Corp for $333 million in cash and stock to expand its holdings of drilling properties (S)
snippet: Plains Exploration and Production Co acquires 3TEC Energy Corp for $333 million in cash and stock to expand its holdings of drilling properties (S)
lead_paragraph: The Plains Exploration and Production Company, an oil and natural gas producer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the 3TEC Energy Corporation for $333 million in cash and stock to expand its holdings of drilling properties. 3TEC stockholders will receive $8.50 and 0.85 share of Plains Exploration common stock for each of their shares, Plains said. Plains said it would also assume $99 million in 3TEC debt. Plains Exploration, based in Houston, produces oil and gas in California, Indiana and Florida. 3TEC Energy, also based in Houston, has oil and gas exploration operations in Texas, Louisiana and Oklahoma.

abstract: Foreign Min Igor Ivanov appeals to Russian oil executives not to confuse Russia's foreign relations by plunging into competing oil export pipeline projects, which will tie Russia's future to neighboring countries for years to come; photo (S)
snippet: Foreign Min Igor Ivanov appeals to Russian oil executives not to confuse Russia's foreign relations by plunging into competing oil export pipeline projects, which will tie Russia's future to neighboring countries for years to come; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Russia's foreign minister appealed to Russian executives to present a united position on how Russia will supply oil to the world. The minister, Igor Ivanov, left, asked executives not to confuse Russia's foreign relations by plunging into competing oil export pipeline projects, which will tie Russia's future to neighboring countries for years to come. Russian oil companies are pushing several new export pipelines, including those to China and Russia's Far North, to get their crude oil to world markets. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

abstract: Russian oil producer Lukoil will begin exploratory work with Kazakhstan's national oil and gas company Kazmunaigaz at site in Kazakhstan's portion of Caspian Sea; Lukoil's chief executive Vagit Y Alekperov says site is close to center of Caspian and that it is thought to contain recoverable reserves of about 730 million barrels of oil (S)
snippet: Russian oil producer Lukoil will begin exploratory work with Kazakhstan's national oil and gas company Kazmunaigaz at site in Kazakhstan's portion of Caspian Sea; Lukoil's chief executive Vagit Y Alekperov says site is close to center of Caspian a...
lead_paragraph: The Russian oil producer Lukoil said it would begin exploratory work with Kazakhstan's national oil and gas company, Kazmunaigaz, at a site in Kazakhstan's portion of the Caspian Sea. Lukoil's chief executive, Vagit Y. Alekperov, said that the site was close to the center of the Caspian and that it was thought to contain recoverable reserves of about 730 million barrels of oil. Lukoil already owns stakes in three projects in Kazakhstan, including a holding in TengizChevroil. Led by ChevronTexaco, TengizChevroil is the largest oil development project in the former Soviet Union including Russia.

abstract: New Orleans and neighboring parishes offer $25,000 each to 300 engineers from ExxonMobil who are being transferred to company's headquarters in Houston, hoping to persuade them to take jobs at other area oil-and-gas companies (S)
snippet: New Orleans and neighboring parishes offer $25,000 each to 300 engineers from ExxonMobil who are being transferred to company's headquarters in Houston, hoping to persuade them to take jobs at other area oil-and-gas companies (S)
lead_paragraph: The closing of ExxonMobil's New Orleans office could send 300 engineers to the company's Houston headquarters. But Mayor C. Ray Nagin said New Orleans and neighboring parishes would offer $25,000 to those who take jobs at other area oil-and-gas companies. ''If we can keep 100 of these engineers in metro New Orleans, we will be sending a message to the corporate world that there is something about doing business in the region that isn't reflected in the bottom line.'' David M. Halbfinger (NYT)

abstract: Japan re
snippet: Japan re
lead_paragraph: Japan reiterated that it is prepared to invest $1 billion to help finance a Russian oil pipeline that would stretch from the Siberian city of Angarsk to Nakhodka, on Russia's eastern coast. The Russian news agency Itar-Tass quoted Yoshiro Kamata, president of the Japan National Oil Corporation, as saying the financing would pay for the construction of an oil terminal and an oil refinery. Japan has been lobbying the Russian government to build the pipeline from Siberia east to the Pacific Ocean. Another proposal would set the route south to China, at half the cost. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)
